qas.question: Where does the word animal come from?
What does the Latin word animalis mean?

answers.text: having breath, having soul or living being

qas.question: The word animal is usually only used to refer to what?

answers.text: non-human members of the kingdom Animalia

qas.question: The biological definition of the word animal refers to all member of what kingdom?
What are some of the creatures included in the kingdom of Animalia?

context: The word "animal" comes from the <a0_0>Latin animalis<a0_0/>, meaning <a1_0>having breath, having soul or living being<a1_0/>. In everyday non-scientific usage the word excludes humans – that is, "animal" is often used to refer only to <a2_0>non-human members of the kingdom Animalia<a2_0/>; often, only closer relatives of humans such as mammals, or mammals and other vertebrates, are meant. The biological definition of the word refers to all members of the kingdom <a3_0>Animalia<a3_0/>, encompassing creatures as diverse as <a4_0>sponges, jellyfish, insects, and humans<a4_0/>.
